channel.title: Chrome for Linux!
channel.description:
It's been released properly at last. "60,000 lines of Linux-specific code written"
http://www.google.com/chrome?hl=en&platform=linux&brand=CHFK

item.title: Chrome for Linux!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:19, topic:318394”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=414870.msg3056989#msg3056989 date=1260566438]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=414870.msg3056713#msg3056713 date=1260537622]

The only problem I’ve had with chrome up to now is no support for netscape plugins (such as flash and java) and no support for add-ons (like adblock and xmarks), but it seems this version of chrome has plugin support, and experimental add-on support. Which almost brings it on-par with firefox, I can’t use all the plugins that I have for firefox yet, so I’m still not switching, but chrome is getting better at least.
[/quote]Uhh, what??? Flash and Java have been working in Chrome since release, i’ve used it since then. An addon system is there by the way, it’s just that nobody knows about it.

The add-on system is still considered experimental according to google, and has only been available at all for less than a month or so.
[/quote]Gmail was considered experimental for years???[/quote]

But this has only been available for a month or so, as I said.

And I agree with mopman on the above issue.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome for Linux!
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:18, topic:318394”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=414870.msg3056713#msg3056713 date=1260537622]

The only problem I’ve had with chrome up to now is no support for netscape plugins (such as flash and java) and no support for add-ons (like adblock and xmarks), but it seems this version of chrome has plugin support, and experimental add-on support. Which almost brings it on-par with firefox, I can’t use all the plugins that I have for firefox yet, so I’m still not switching, but chrome is getting better at least.
[/quote]Uhh, what??? Flash and Java have been working in Chrome since release, i’ve used it since then. An addon system is there by the way, it’s just that nobody knows about it.

The add-on system is still considered experimental according to google, and has only been available at all for less than a month or so.[/quote]Gmail was considered experimental for years???

item.title: Chrome for Linux!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:12, topic:318394”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=414870.msg3056453#msg3056453 date=1260501481]
The only problem I’ve had with chrome up to now is no support for netscape plugins (such as flash and java) and no support for add-ons (like adblock and xmarks), but it seems this version of chrome has plugin support, and experimental add-on support. Which almost brings it on-par with firefox, I can’t use all the plugins that I have for firefox yet, so I’m still not switching, but chrome is getting better at least.
[/quote]Uhh, what??? Flash and Java have been working in Chrome since release, i’ve used it since then. An addon system is there by the way, it’s just that nobody knows about it.[/quote]

The add-on system is still considered experimental according to google, and has only been available at all for less than a month or so.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome for Linux!
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

T4_:

Using chrome, only thing I don’t like is that incognito mode hides the user-agent information.

Well after all, it is incognito mode so you probably want as little information transmitted as possible.

What situation would you need incognito mode and the user-agent?

Read full topic

item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

Addons are only in Beta right now, I just tried to install them on the windows version and Google told me to download the new Beta browser

chrome.google.com

AdBlock

The most popular Chrome extension, with over 40 million users! Blocks ads all over the web.

Everyones favourite firefox extension!

Which almost brings it on-par with firefox, I can’t use all the plugins that I have for firefox yet, so I’m still not switching, but chrome is getting better at least.[/quote]Uhh, what??? item.title: Chrome for Linux!

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The only problem I’ve had with chrome up to now is no support for netscape plugins (such as flash and java) and no support for add-ons (like adblock and xmarks), but it seems this version of chrome has plugin support, and experimental add-on support. Which almost brings it on-par with firefox, I can’t use all the plugins that I have for firefox yet, so I’m still not switching, but chrome is getting better at least.

item.title: Chrome for Linux!
item.dc:creator: @Bebemycat2 Bebe
item.description:
@Bebemycat2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:2, topic:318394”]Don’t know why in the world they would have had to write that many lines of linux-specific code. Ridiculous.

I’ll stick with firefox though.[/quote]
Agreed. I’ve never been a fan of Chrome. The only two browsers I’ve ever LOVED were Firefox and Opera. All other browsers either sucked, were mediocore, or they just didn’t fit right with me. idk. Firefox is a great web browser for my purposes and I don’t see a reason to change.

Read full topic
